# Bipolar Junction Transistor ( BJT)

Amplification is the process of linearly increasing the amplitude of an electrical signal and is one of the major properties of a transistor\.

BJT exhibits current gain \(called beta\)\.

<span style="color:#336600">When a BJT is biased in the active \(or linear\) region\, as previously described\, the BE junction has a low resistance due to forward bias and the BC junction has a high resistance due to reverse bias\.</span>

![](l4.5-bjt-amplifier-img/l45-bjt-amplifier_1.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Basic transistor amplifier circuit with ac source voltage V</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">s</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> and dc bias voltage V</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">BB</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> superimposed\.</span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

The purpose of biasing is to establish a Q\-point about which variations in current and voltage can occur in response to an ac input signal\.

<span style="color:#336600">In applications where small signal voltages must be amplified—such as from an antenna or a microphone—variations about the Q\-point are relatively small\. </span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">Linear BJT\-Amplifier:\-</span>

A  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __linear amplifier __ </span> provides amplification of a signal without any distortion so that the output signal is an exact  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _amplified replica _ </span> of the input signal\.

<span style="color:#c00000"> _Example opposite shows\, A voltage\-divider biased transistor with a sinusoidal ac source\._ </span>

<span style="color:#336600"> _The coupling capacitors block dc and thus prevent the internal source resistance\, R_ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> _s_ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> _\, and the load resistance\, R_ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> _L_ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> _\, from changing the dc bias voltages at the base and collector\. _ </span>

The capacitors ideally appear as shorts to the AC signal voltage\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">An amplifier with voltage\-divider bias driven by an ac voltage source with an internal resistance\, Rs\.</span>

![](l4.5-bjt-amplifier-img/l45-bjt-amplifier_2.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">Linear BJT\-Amplifier:\-</span>

<span style="color:#336600"> _As the sinusoidal collector current increases\, the collector voltage decreases\. _ </span>

The collector current varies above and below its Q\-point value\, ICQ\, in phase with the base current\.

VCEQ\, 1800 out of phase with the base voltage\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">An amplifier with voltage\-divider bias driven by an ac voltage source with an internal resistance\, Rs\.</span>

![](l4.5-bjt-amplifier-img/l45-bjt-amplifier_3.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff"> _A transistor always produces a phase inversion between the base voltage and the collector voltage\._ </span>
